question: Mama, my story.
answer: Again?

question: Tell me.
answer: Your father had been very ill, We thought he would die, and some animals had died.

question: Cow.
answer: And a yak. And chickens. And we had four years of bad crops, all the farmers did. In the night, I knew you were coming. At dawn, you were born.

question: Tell me.
answer: You were a beautiful baby. So calm.

question: No cried?
answer: Maybe, just a little. And that day, your father got better. He named you Lhamo. "The Protector."

question: I know.
answer: Go to sleep, Lhamo.

question: Me.
answer: No. This must stop.

question: Me. Here.
answer: I am the father. You sit there.

question: What is the harm?
answer: I go away. Look, mama, I go away. Far, far, far.

question: Oh, no. Where will he go?
answer: Far, far away.

question: Good day. Please, come in, so cold. Of course, please, this way. Your servant may use the kitchen.
answer: Mine. Mine.

question: Mine. Mine.
answer: Mine.

question: Please.
answer: I will give it to, if you can tell me who I am.

question: Say, Kumbum Monastery.
answer: Kumbum. It is not far away.

question: It is not far at all, and it is a beautiful place. And your big brother is abbott there. You will not be alone.
answer: I will be very smart.

question: You will be fine. You will be a fine monk. Om mani padme hum. Om mani padme hum. Your father had been very sick. He had been sick from the time you began growing in me. We thought he would die.
answer: Cow.

question: Yes. A cow had died. One night, you stopped all your moving, and I said to your sister, "His time has come."
answer: Me. First break of day.

question: At dawn, you were born. One eye was closed, and your sister opened it with her thumb. We gave you the sweet drink.
answer: I pooped.

question: You did. We washed you and wrapped you in sheepskin and took you to your father. That day he father got better
answer: I miss my brother.

question: I miss him too. Sera Monastery? From Lhasa?
answer: This is yours, you say. What else belongs to you? Yes, those are yours. With permission? "Kundun" He is the Presence.

question: My oldest boy is an incarnation.
answer: So is your youngest. I wish you long life.

question: I will be back in a few days.
answer: How many?

question: Two.
answer: This many?

question: You have all the room.
answer: Don't be a baby, move over.

question: You move.
answer: You! You think you are so big!

question: I am the good one. You be bad. The bad man.
answer: My name is Norbu, Holiness. I will be good, you be bad.

question: I'm on a big mountain and hitting at the bad men. And after the game, we're going to trade. You just stay over there, no, there!, Norbu, and I will shoot at you. I want your land. I take it. I am stronger.
answer: I am braver.

question: I have more men.
answer: Today you lose. Tomorrow you may win. Things change, Kundun.

question: I believe that the Regent is asking for too high a reward for his part in finding the Dalai Lama. Too much money, too much land.
answer: Tenzin Gyatso peeks through a door at the great assembly.

question: Our treasuries are empty. Our army is depleted. He would have us pull the hair from our noses.
answer: The Dalai Lama is confused, but continues listening.

question: We cannot allow it. Right now, we have a only a small Chinese mission in Lhasa, the first since the Thirteenth Dalai Lama threw them out in 1912. The road would increase the size of that mission. The Chinese would try to control our trade, as they did once before, control our contact with the outside world.
answer: The Lord Chamberlain touches the boy's shoulder and Tenzin Gyatso leaves his hiding place, as the speaker's voice fades away.

question: One night, not too long ago, an old monk saw a woman in that very same hallway where you ran away. She carried a basket in her arms, a big, heavy basket, and the old monk cautiously approached. She opened her basket and showed what she had. Heads. Human heads. Only the heads.
answer: Is that true or pretend?

question: It is a story, you decide.
answer: Pretend.

question: As you say.
answer: "I be an island for those who seek one, a lamp for light." "May I be a bed for all who wish to rest, and a slave for all who want a slave." "May I be wishing jewel, a magic vase... I want to go down there.

question: You can only go with attendants and a big ceremony.
answer: I want to run down the street. I want to buy a toy. Eat from the shops.

question: You cannot.
answer: I want to be a shepherd, taking those goats and cows out to the hillside.

question: But you are not a shepherd, you are the Dalai Lama.
answer: Maybe in the next life, the world will not need a Dalai Lama. Little ones first, only little ones.

question: Maybe in the next life, the world will not need a Dalai Lama. Little ones first, only little ones.
answer: I am sorry, Lhamo.

question: It is alright, Father. Go away.
answer: Not the way to talk to people.

question: Can I do anything I want?
answer: No.

question: But, I am in charge.
answer: Are you? Of whom?

question: Can I save the sheep from going to the market? So they don't die.
answer: You could buy them.

question: Do I have money?
answer: What do you think?

question: Do you have money?
answer: I do, now.

question: And you have horses? You love horses.
answer: I do, beautiful horses. Thank you, Holiness.

question: Will you buy the sheep for me?
answer: Where will you keep them?

question: Here. We'll collect them.
answer: I will buy them for you.

question: Can I free the prisoners?
answer: Hmmm.

question: I have news. The Regent has resigned his post.
answer: Is he a bad man? Norbu says he is "lavish" and "willful". "How can he give you monk's vows if he has not kept them himself?"

question: Well, some say. It's not for you to worry about. Another will be chosen.
answer: He was always nice to me. He found me. He saw me in his dreams.

question: I turn you over again, today, Lhamo. One day, you will not be able to come running to us.
answer: But you will always be here?

question: Me?
answer: You will always!

question: I have one more piece of news. A baby is coming.
answer: Oh, Mama! Who will it be?

question: Oh, no! Who can it be?
answer: My teeth! My teeth are in here! My old teeth!

question: My teeth! My teeth are in here! My old teeth!
answer: "I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra."

question: You recite! You recite!
answer: "I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra." "Until I attain enlightenment."

question: I would like you to be my new Regent.
answer: The Four Noble Truths.

question: The Four Noble Truths, as taught by the Lord Sakyamuni Buddha are
answer: I accept it. What is suffering?

question: True suffering arises from contaminated actions and afflictions. Birth, illness, grief, old age, poverty, pain, death - these are surferings.
answer: I accept it. What are the causes of suffering?

question: The causes of suffering arise from true sources. Attachment, desire, envy, hatred, greed, unkindness, wrong view and so forth - these are some causes of suffering.
answer: How does one progress from the realization of one Noble Truth to another?

question: We will have to think about that. I need to squeeze this brain.
answer: Answer.

question: When one understands that he causes some of his own suffering, needlessly, then he looks for the causes in his own life.
answer: I accept it.

question: Oh, nicely done, Norbu. I will get you.
answer: May I listen to the news with you, Holiness?

question: Please. How big is Tibet's army? Is that big?
answer: No. Not very big.

question: The Regent is adding men. And he bought rifles and ammunition from India. Mountain guns, too. Will we be in this war?
answer: No. This war is almost over.

question: Will we ever be in war?
answer: We have enemies.

question: The Chinese.
answer: Yes.

question: Where is Poland? Where is Pearl Harbor?
answer: In the Pacific Ocean. It is an island. American territory.

question: Where is Alsace?
answer: I do not know, Holiness.

question: This is Tibet. And this is China.
answer: Ahh.

question: Certainly, we are safe in Tibet.
answer: We hope, Kundun.

question: What was the warning of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama?
answer: He warned about the future of Tibet.

question: Tell me.
answer: When it is time.

question: I am sorry for you to have to witness this, Kundun.
answer: Look here!

question: Tragic. Unnecessary. Holiness? I have a letter. The Thirteenth Dalai Lama's warning. He wrote to you, the year before he died. The year before you were born. "It may happen, that here in Tibet, religion and government will be attacked both from without and within. Unless we guard our own country..." "...it will now happen that the Dalai and Panchen Lamas, the Father and the Son, and all the revered holders of the faith, will disappear and become nameless." "Monks and their monasteries will be destroyed. The rule of law will be weakened. The lands and properties will be seized. They themselves will be forced to serve their enemies or wander the country like beggars."
answer: What can I do? I am only a boy.

question: Taktra Rinpoche, I understand there was an attempt on your life.
answer: It is possible, Holiness.

question: You are unharmed?
answer: Completely.

question: Good. Where is Reting Rinpoche now?
answer: He has been imprisoned, here in the Potala, Holiness.

question: The Sera monks have surrendered?
answer: It is calm.

question: The war is over. This is a time in when nations are redefining themselves.
answer: So, Tibet, too, needs to define itself.

question: Yes. As a free country. But our attempts have proven futile. We continue to be badly outmaneuvered by the Chinese.
answer: Can India help us?

question: India is a newly independent nation. They are struggling. India is in no position to help us.
answer: Britain?

question: Britain chooses not to.
answer: And, America?

question: America, we shall see.
answer: Ask the Chinese mission to leave our country. Immediately.

question: Quite simple. Yes. Good.
answer: I shall send a letter to America, to the President, informing him of our problem. I want Reting Rinpoche well cared for. He is my teacher. He found me. Listen to this, Norbu.

question: The Communist have control of China.
answer: The Dalai Lama is listening. He stands taller than the first time we caught him eavesdropping. He still is not a part of this assembly, but he doesn't seem to care if he is spotted.

question: Now, as his great army, stands idle on our borders, Chairman Mao has presented Tibet with three demands:
answer: Shock on the face of His Holiness.

question: Two, Tibet's defenses must be handled by China. Three, all political and trade matters concerning foreign countries must be conducted through China. And do you believe that the Tibetan government will be allowed to continue to function as it is? Do you believe that our religion will be protected? These are not the Chinese we know. These are Communists.
answer: Tenzin Gyatso looks at his advisor, and then, he closes the door as the demand for his enthronement continues.

question: If we agree that we are part of China, nothing else will matter. Not trade, not defense. We will be lost.
answer: What would you do, Holiness?

question: What should I do about my doubt, Teacher?
answer: It is a difficult situation.

question: I mean, my doubt. Why me? Am I Him?
answer: Doubt is an affliction. Reliquish it. Accept.

question: I believe we must make no concesions to the Chinese. But, I am one voice. The Dalai Lama has always trusted in the forces of Buddha. Let us consult the protective deities.
answer: We should not accept any conditions from the Chinese. Enter.

question: Enter. Yes.
answer: They crossed the river, Holiness. They have invaded in six locations, Chando Province, Kham, eastern Tibet.

question: What is the size of our army, now?
answer: Eight thousand, five hundred, soldiers and officers. We have recently requested mortars, anti-aircraft guns and ammunition from India. We have several hundred in the area.

question: Has anyone died? One man. A man has died. One man is too many. What do the people say, Norbu?
answer: Tibetan officials have retreated from Chamdo. They are scared and running. The Chinese strategy has destroyed the heart of our defense forces. Chamdo falls, several other villages are lost. You know what happens. The road to Lhasa will be wide open. The people want you made Dalai Lama.

question: Then, I am lucky. I am still too young.
answer: These are dangerous times. They want the Dalai Lama to lead them.

question: But, I have no experience.
answer: Oh, but you do, Kundun. Who else would be here?

question: "To the members of the United Nations: "Tibetans have for long lived a cloistered life in their mountain fastness, remote and aloof..."
answer: I was never alone. Two Chinese were with me every minute of the day. Their talk is always of liberation and helpfulness. They put their words like honey on a knife, but if you lick the honey, you will bleed.

question: Tell me.
answer: They think they have convinced me. They think I am on their side. They have allowed me to leave Kumbum and come to Lhasa believing that I will try to turn you to their ways. If I do not succeed, I am to eliminate you.

question: You, kill me?
answer: Eliminate you. Don't eat all those sweets. You'll get sick.

question: Do you remember the day I came to your monastery, when I was a baby? And you comforted me?
answer: I do.

question: I remember, too, actually. I was frightened then. I am frightened now.
answer: The Chinese have one goal. The complete dissolution of our nation. The destruction of our culture. There is no room for Buddha in their world.

question: We cannot.
answer: This is not a fight to put bread just in one's own mouth. This is a fight for Tibet.

question: Buddha teaches that we must learn from our enemy. We have compassion for all people.
answer: These are not human beings. They are worse than ghosts. You are in great danger. The Dalai Lama cannot fall into Chinese hands. You must flee.

question: How could I ever leave?
answer: It may not be your decision to make.

question: I accept it. We shall send delegations to America, India, Nepal and Great Britain, in hope that these countries will intervene on our behalf. We have telegraphed our appeal to the United Nations and await its reply. I am sending a delegation to China to negotiate the Chinese withdrawal. It seems that I must depart Lhasa. The majority wills it. Lukhangwa and Lobsang Tashi? I am making you my Prime Ministers. You will stay here. You must always keep me informed, no matter how bad the news. I want plain information. Today, I declare a general amnesty.
answer: It's time to take this down.

question: You will not come?
answer: No, Holiness.

question: Am I running away?
answer: The people will cry when they learn you are gone. But they would all want you safe. Let me take this. You must study very hard, do not neglect the holy things during this time.

question: I will miss you.
answer: We have had fun, you and I. Fun for a little boy in an old palace.

question: We have.
answer: You have grown up very good.

question: And you have grown older and your chin has grown balder.
answer: Tonight, Kundun, you see the world. You place your feet on the shepherd boy's path. "The Gods will be avenged." I will send it to you. It will work.

question: All quiet?
answer: Yes, Holiness.

question: Where are you from?
answer: Kham, Holiness.

question: Your people are very brave. They are fighting the Chinese. No one can stop them. Not even me.
answer: Khambas are wild men.

question: I worry about them.
answer: Do not worry, Holiness. They fight for you. They are under your protection. Holiness, this has come for you.

question: Eighteen, wonderful. Did you love your husband, before you married?
answer: I did not know him before I married him. I loved his brother, but then, I married his brother, too. He is dead now.

question: Hmm.
answer: The land has stayed in the family. We work together. The nobleman is not too bad.

question: Does he treat you fairly?
answer: Not too bad. Rich is rich, poor is poor. We are different. Are you married?

question: No.
answer: Too young?

question: Much too young.
answer: Look for a strong woman, not too occupied with her beauty. Look for a woinan who keeps her hands busy. Look for a kind heart.

question: Like my mother.
answer: I see that.

question: This little brother was terribly sweet. When he died, my mother was so sad. A lama said to her, before the little brother was laid out for burial, take a bit of butter and rub a spot on his skin. He will come back to you, you will see. So, my mother did this, and a few years later, a new boy was born. He does, a little spot where the butter had been. What do you think? You decide. Soft. Nice. I have a good friend back in Lhasa. He has a very poor beard, with a little spot on his chin where no hair grows. It feels like that.
answer: Of the Tibetan delegations sent abroad, all have been turned away.

question: All?
answer: Britain, Nepal, America, India. All of those governments have refused to meet with our representatives.

question: And the United Nations? Surely?
answer: The United Nations voted not to hear our appeal.

question: So, we must face China and all her might alone.
answer: Yes. Most of the Chamdo region is now in Chinese hands. There is a report from Chamdo which makes quite clear that, unless some settlement can soon be reached, Communist troops will soon be marching on Lhasa.

question: With much bloodshed.
answer: I am afraid.

question: Ngabo did not have the state seal. He could not sign.
answer: Yes, but they say he did.

question: Holiness?
answer: Yes.

question: General Chiang Chin-wu, the Chinese representative, is en route to Dromo. He is coming to meet you.
answer: Then, we shall meet.

question: Then, we shall meet.
answer: Dalai Lama.

question: General Chiang.
answer: We bring greetings from Chairman Mao.

question: Thank you. Please sit.
answer: Have you heard the terms of the Seventeen Point Agreement?

question: I have.
answer: I have a copy for you. We come in genuine friendship. I am certain you wish to return to Lhasa. Do you have plans to return soon, Dalai Lama?

question: Soon.
answer: Good. Our first request is that you allow us to build a road. You have no roads in Tibet. We can discuss the plans in Lhasa. When you return.

question: Let me see the agreement. Counterfeit. I thought he would be some kind of monster, even with horns growing out of his head. But, he is only a man, just an ordinary human being, like myself. Life is always a lesson.
answer: Your Prime Ministers, support the proposal that you return to Lhasa. On the opposite hand, some officials urge you not to return. They believe you should leave now, for India.

question: If I were to go into exile, could we expect any serious assistance, from India, suppose? At this point, the most likely result of a foreign pact is war. Tibet, at war? No. China is close, America is far away. After countless people die, China would still, always, be close. We will work with what we have.
answer: And as for your own safety, Holiness?

question: No, Norbu!
answer: I hate meeting here, this tribute to the past! I demand a less formal meeting place. I am not a foreigner! I refuse to be treated like one.

question: You see here thangkas of the Fifth Dalai Lama, the founder of our government. It is tradition at formal meetings for these thangkas to be hung.
answer: Superstitions. Tibet is part of a modern nation. I want the songs stopped.

question: Songs? What songs? I have no authority to ban singing in my country.
answer: You must also do something about the public meetings. I see this, memorandum circulating, with Tibetan grievances.

question: You must also do something about the public meetings. I see this, memorandum circulating, with Tibetan grievances.
answer: You have cracked a man's skull and that crack has not healed. It is too soon to expect him to be your friend.

question: We are simply respecting the terms of the Seventeen Point Agreement.
answer: Are you, General?

question: We want 2,000 more tons of barley distributed.
answer: Impossible! You will bring famine down on the people of Tibet with these insatiable demands! More food, the best land for your soldiers to camp.

question: The People's Liberation Army pays for all food and lodging.
answer: So far, they do. But, the quantity, it does not exist. You will have to re- evaluate your needs.

question: How much tea do you drink, Prime Minister?
answer: It depends on the quality. And, that it be Indian. Why is it necessary for the Chinese to keep so many soldiers in Lhasa?

question: To protect. To serve you. Chairman Mao wants you to feel that China belongs to you now.
answer: Chairman Mao can keep China. Just give us back Tibet.

question: Plans for absorbing the Tibetan army into the People's Army will soon be finalized.
answer: I will not approve it.

question: Then, we will begin with replacing the Tibetan flag with the flag of the Motherland.
answer: And we will begin with tearing it down.

question: And we will begin with tearing it down.
answer: I am so sorry.

question: It must be done. We can no longer meet with the Chinese, they refuse us.
answer: I accept your resignations. There will be no new Prime Ministers.

question: You will face great difficulties, Holiness.
answer: They have taken away our silence.

question: They have taken away our silence.
answer: The mission of China is to bring progress to Tibet. Develop its natural resources. Help its people develop democracy. We welcome you, Tibet, back to the Motherland! I am so glad that Tibet has come back to the Motherland. You must inform me at once if any of our people abuse the Tibetans trust and good nature.

question: I have great hopes for the future of our co-operation.
answer: It is too early to implement all the clauses of the Seventeen Point Agreement. We will establish a Preparatory Committee for the Autonomous Region of Tibet. The pace of reform must meet with the desires of the Tibetan people. Changes must be made slowly, as you, yourself, judge necessary.

question: I am happy to hear you say this, Chairman Mao. I have created a reform committee to investigate grievances and we have abolished Inherited Tax, and forgiven all money owed the Government by people who are unable to pay.
answer: Good. Very good. Tibet is a great country. A a wonderful history. Long ago, you even conquered part of China. But now you have fallen behind and we want to help you. In twenty years time you could be ahead of us. Then it will be your turn to help China. You know, I have great respect for your Lord Buddha. He was anti-caste. Anti-corruption. Anti-exploitation. For some, politics and religion can mix.

question: For me, I think such a mix is crucial.
answer: Have a sweet. Made in my home province. The kind my mother used to make.

question: "If moral discipline is learned from the beginning, one possesses the root for achieving higher rebirth. A staircase for achieving liberation. An antidote eliminating misery and sorrow. Without discipline there is no method." I am thinking of becoming a Communist Party Member. I like what I see of Marxism. It is based on equality and justice for all. I believe Chairman Mao wishes the best for our people. Our path must be non-violence. Co-operation.
answer: Ah, Dalai Lama, thank you for coming so late.

question: I leave tomorrow.
answer: Yes, I am aware. How has your time in China been?

question: I have been greatly impressed by your accomplishments. Industrial progress. Great efficiency. Your people are capable and courteous.
answer: You have a lot to learn about organization. How to draw out people's opinions. How to make key decisions. Train your young Tibetans. When I make contact with you, I want to reach you through a Tibetan. Your attitude is good, you know. I understand you well. But you need to learn this Well, let me walk you to your car. Take care of your health.

question: He will betray us. I had relinquished doubt. Are you happy? I ask them to stop, to lay down their guns.
answer: The Khamba's gun is his most prized possession. I admire them so. They face a modern, well equipped army, and still, they fight. Land reform is underway in Amdo. The large estates are being confiscated and redistributed. Landlords are being punished.

question: A beggar can be called a landlord if he disapproves of the Chinese. I have always asked for plain information. Just the truth.
answer: The Communists put their guns in the hands of the Khamba children and force the child to kill the parent. They have dropped bombs on the monastery of Lithang in Kham. It has been destroyed. Women and children, trying to escape from the fighting, have been shot with machine guns, fired from airplanes.

question: The pursuit of non-violence. Very difficult.
answer: Non-violence means co-operation when it is possible. Resistance, when it is not.

question: We have decided that no drastic changes will take place in Tibet for six years. This should make you happy. It seems a revolt has broken out in the east. We have decided that the Tibetan army must be used against the Khamba guerrillas.
answer: I will not approve it. You have bombed on peaceful people.

question: We must deal with these reactionaries!
answer: No. We are peace loving people. I am afraid we cannot trust you.

question: We are here to heal the people of Tibet. You need reform. You have no sense of what is good for your people. We are here to liberate you!
answer: I burn here, but I am not suppose to let the smoke show. Yes, we need reform. The monasteries. Communications. Schools. But we want change for Tibet, as Tibet needs it, not for China. Buddha is our physician, General, he will heal us. Comapssion and enlightnement will set us free. You can not liberate me I can only liberate myself.

question: I burn here, but I am not suppose to let the smoke show. Yes, we need reform. The monasteries. Communications. Schools. But we want change for Tibet, as Tibet needs it, not for China. Buddha is our physician, General, he will heal us. Comapssion and enlightnement will set us free. You can not liberate me I can only liberate myself.
answer: They will take Lhasa next.

question: The people will not allow it. "I rejoice in the Awakening of the Buddhas, and also in the spiritual levels of their Sons." "And with gladness I rejoice in the ocean of virtue from developing an awakening mind that wishes all beings to be happy..." "As well as in the deeds that bring them benefit. "Thus by the virtue collected Through all that I have done, May the pain of every living creature be completely cleared away."
answer: The crowd will not disperse until you give your assurance that you will not attend the Chinese festivities. Many who have been invited to dine with the Chinese do not return home.

question: I will not go.
answer: I will alert the Chinese delegation.
